segments.en: Linked Discourses 1
4. The Satullapa Group
38. A Splinter
So I have heard.

segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati maddakucchismiṃ migadāye.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha in the Maddakucchi deer park.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavato pādo sakalikāya khato hoti.
segments.en: Now at that time the Buddha’s foot had been cut by a splinter.

segments.pli: Bhusā sudaṃ bhagavato vedanā vattanti sārīrikā vedanā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā asātā amanāpā;
segments.en: The Buddha was stricken by harrowing pains; physical feelings that were painful, sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, and disagreeable.

segments.pli: tā sudaṃ bhagavā sato sampajāno adhivāseti avihaññamāno.
segments.en: But he endured with mindfulness and situational awareness, without worrying.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā catugguṇaṃ saṅghāṭiṃ paññāpetvā dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyaṃ kappeti pāde pādaṃ accādhāya sato sampajāno.
segments.en: And then he spread out his outer robe folded in four and laid down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware.

segments.pli: Atha kho sattasatā satullapakāyikā devatāyo abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ maddakucchiṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu.
segments.en: Then, late at night, several glorious deities of the Satullapa Group, lighting up the entire Maddukucchi, went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side.

segments.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho ekā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
segments.en: Standing to one side, one deity was inspired to exclaim in the Buddha’s presence:
“The ascetic Gotama is such an elephant, sir!

segments.pli: nāgavatā ca samuppannā sārīrikā vedanā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā asātā amanāpā sato sampajāno adhivāseti avihaññamāno”ti.
segments.en: And as an elephant, he endures painful physical feelings that have come up—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, and disagreeable—with mindfulness and situational awareness, without worrying.”

segments.pli: Atha kho aparā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
segments.en: Then another deity was inspired to exclaim in the Buddha’s presence:
“The ascetic Gotama is such a lion, sir!

segments.pli: sīhavatā ca samuppannā sārīrikā vedanā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā asātā amanāpā sato sampajāno adhivāseti avihaññamāno”ti.
segments.en: And as a lion, he endures painful physical feelings … without worrying.”

segments.pli: Atha kho aparā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
segments.en: Then another deity was inspired to exclaim in the Buddha’s presence:
“The ascetic Gotama is such a thoroughbred, sir!

segments.pli: ājānīyavatā ca samuppannā sārīrikā vedanā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā asātā amanāpā sato sampajāno adhivāseti avihaññamāno”ti.
segments.en: And as a thoroughbred, he endures painful physical feelings … without worrying.”

segments.pli: Atha kho aparā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
segments.en: Then another deity was inspired to exclaim in the Buddha’s presence:
“The ascetic Gotama is such a chief bull, sir!

segments.pli: nisabhavatā ca samuppannā sārīrikā vedanā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā asātā amanāpā sato sampajāno adhivāseti avihaññamāno”ti.
segments.en: And as a chief bull, he endures painful physical feelings … without worrying.”

segments.pli: Atha kho aparā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
segments.en: Then another deity was inspired to exclaim in the Buddha’s presence:
“The ascetic Gotama is such a behemoth, sir!

segments.pli: dhorayhavatā ca samuppannā sārīrikā vedanā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā asātā amanāpā sato sampajāno adhivāseti avihaññamāno”ti.
segments.en: And as a behemoth, he endures painful physical feelings … without worrying.”

segments.pli: Atha kho aparā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
segments.en: Then another deity was inspired to exclaim in the Buddha’s presence:
“The ascetic Gotama is truly tamed, sir!

segments.pli: dantavatā ca samuppannā sārīrikā vedanā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā asātā amanāpā sato sampajāno adhivāseti avihaññamāno”ti.
segments.en: And as someone tamed, he endures painful physical feelings … without worrying.”

segments.pli: Atha kho aparā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
segments.en: Then another deity was inspired to exclaim in the Buddha’s presence:

segments.pli: “passa samādhiṃ subhāvitaṃ cittañca suvimuttaṃ, na cābhinataṃ na cāpanataṃ na ca sasaṅkhāraniggayhavāritagataṃ.
segments.en: “See, his immersion is so well developed, and his mind is so well freed—not leaning forward or pulling back, and not held in place by forceful suppression.

segments.pli: Yo evarūpaṃ purisanāgaṃ purisasīhaṃ purisaājānīyaṃ purisanisabhaṃ purisadhorayhaṃ purisadantaṃ atikkamitabbaṃ maññeyya kimaññatra adassanā”ti.
segments.en: If anyone imagines that they can overcome such an elephant of a man, a lion of a man, a thoroughbred of a man, a chief bull of a man, a behemoth of a man, a tamed man—what is that but a failure to see?”
“Learned in the five Vedas, brahmins practice
mortification for a full century.
But their minds are not properly freed,
for those of base character don’t cross to the far shore.
Seized by craving, attached to precepts and observances,
they practice rough mortification for a hundred years.
But their minds are not properly freed,
for those of base character don’t cross to the far shore.
Someone who’s fond of conceit can’t be tamed,
and someone without immersion can’t be a sage.
Living negligent alone in the wilderness,
they can’t pass beyond Death’s domain.”
“Having given up conceit, serene within oneself,
with a healthy heart, everywhere released;
living diligent alone in the wilderness,
they pass beyond Death’s domain.”

suttaplex.blurb: A series of deities praise the Buddha’s resilience and composure when his foot is injured by a stone.
